abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, for despite political, and financial crises,
            the support provided by the project in developing social
            safety nets, ensured social protection, and a sustainable
            likelihood. Several lessons are drawn from the project,
            first, that project management, in the context of weak
            institutional capacity, requires continuous technical
            support, particularly in the early stages of the project,
            while management continuity, provides the stability for
            implementation, in line with appropriate project design.
            Conflicting rules, and regulations on the release of
            Government funding led to delays in fund transfers, thus,
            release procedures should be specified early, during
            appraisal, timing the Government's budget approval, to
            project initiation, preventing lack of funds. Furthermore,
            when financing of social programs becomes almost fiscally
            independent from budgetary transfers, payroll tax rates may
            be very high, risking distortions in the labor market, and
            slowing economic growth. Instead, social programs design
            should incorporate aspects of equity, and affordability, and
            social policies should be consistent to the country's
            institutional capacity. Thus, training of staff, responsible
            of social programs becomes paramount.
